Mr. Batbileg, 34, is an accountant in a military unit of the Mongolian Armed Forces. He has been working as an accountant for twelve years and lives with his son and wife in Kherlen, a western boundary town of Mongolia. 

His family owns a house which was built long before they moved into it. Lately, his house has been becoming very old and cold to live in because it does not have any wall insulation. Therefore, he is planning to install insulation before this winter. After the insulation is installed, the house will be warmer and more economical for fuel usage. The loan he is taking will be dedicated to purchasing some building materials to renovate his house.

loans.use: to purchase some building materials to renovate his house.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en: Leonila is 55 years old and lives in the village of Guba Clarin, Misamis Occidental with her husband and 10 children. She and her husband earn a living by growing corn, and generate about PHP 5,900 in income per crop. She has been in this line of work for more than 12 years and is applying for a PHP 3,000 loan from GDMPC to buy two sacks of fertilizer for her next crop. Her goal for the future is to expand her farm.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to use on her farm.

loans.name: Suvd-Erdene

texts.en: Mrs. Suvd-Erdene is 29 years old and earns a living as a beautician. Her salon is in downtown Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She is single and lives with her son in an apartment that she rents. Her salon is only three months old but already has many permanent customers because she provides excellent service. She is applying for this loan to buy more equipment and perfume.

loans.use: to buy equipment and perfume for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Badam

texts.en: For the last several years, Mr. Badam has earned a living by providing transportation services in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. He is widowed and lives with his son and his sister's family in a suburb near the city. In the future, he plans to increase his income by opening a grocery store adjacent to his house. He is beginning to build the store, and is applying for a loan for MNT 1,500,000 to buy the materials he needs to continue the job.

loans.use: to buy materials he needs to build a store.

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en:
Bienvinida, a 41-year-old mother of seven school-age children, is married to Mr. Darion, who is a carpenter and a farmer. They live in the village of Guba, Clarin Misamis Occidental.

Bienvinida has been planting and harvesting corn for sale for about 11 years and earns approximately PHP 7,600 every cropping. A member of GDMPC, she is requesting her first loan of Php 5000 to purchase fertilizers for her cornfield. The extra profits arising from the loan will go toward the education of her children. She hopes that her business will remain successful.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Kheng's Group

texts.en:
This group comes from Kompong Chhnang province, Cambodia. They have joined together to ask for some funds from HKL and Kiva in the sum of KHR4,000,000. They have the same purpose in using this fund. They mainly will use it for the pig raising business. 

Among them, Mrs. Kheng was chosen to be a leader of the group. She cultivates rice crops alongside her husband. She is an industrious woman in working on her farmland. Typically, she is able to earn around $2.50 per day. She has 2 children who are single and attend a local public school. Kheng intends to create more income through a pig fattening business, so she has applied for a loan from Kvia to buy some piglets to start this business. With the increase in income, she will save for the business expansion in the future and also for the education of her children. She wants to send them to the university after they finish high school.

loans.use: to buy some piglets for raising.

loans.name: Gandaria 6 Group

texts.en: Puji is 32 years old and married with two children. Her husband works as an employee. Her husband's income can feed the family, but now she has a six month new born baby. She wants to have more income to buy milk for her baby. This is her first loan with VisionFund Indonesia. With this loan she wants to start producing and selling nasi uduk (Indonesian rice dish). She hopes by doing this business she can still take care of her baby and get more income. She hopes this business will grow and she can save for her children's education. Other group members will use their loans to help their businesses which include selling fried bananas and selling clothes on credit.

loans.use: to pay for rice, tofu, tempe [a soy product], and vegetables.

loans.name: T Teofista

texts.en:
Teofista is 57 years old and married. She has 9 adult children. She lives in Dalingap, Clarin Misamis Occidental.

To earn a living, Teofista owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, planting and harvesting corn for sale. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn. She has been in this business for over 10 years. Doing this type of business she has a return in the amount of Php 8,000 a month.

Early this year she joined GDMPC to gain financial assistance for her corn production. She is requesting a loan of Php 5000 to purchase fertilizers and other farm equipment for the better nourishment of her corn. In the future she plans to save money for her older age.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm equipment for the better nourishment of her corn

loans.name: Calixta

texts.en:
Calixta is 39 years old and married.  She has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Pantaon, Ozamiz City. Her husband is a farmer.

To earn a living, Calixta owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialized retail store. Calixta decided to provide for the needs of the community. She offers different kinds of products, like foods for snacks, noodles, eggs, sugar, soap, and others.  Calixta has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Calixta joined GDMPC to gain financial access from the cooperative to help expand her business. This is the fifth cycle of loans taken from the cooperative. She is requesting this fifth cycle a loan of 6000 Php to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. In the future, Calixta plans to make her business bigger to have an additional return every month, because she plans to renovate her house from the income she generates from her business.

loans.use: Purchase more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Thun's Group

texts.en:
Thun is 56 years old.  She is married and has 2 children. They both work on the farm to help the family. She has one granddaughter who goes to school and is living with her.  Thun leads a group of two members.

Thun has been growing maize for almost 10 years to earn a living. This is her third loan with VisionFund. She is applying for a loan to buy maize seeds and fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to grow more maize, which will enable her to earn more income to feed her family, buy necessary household goods, and also keep her granddaughter in school.

loans.use: to buy maize seeds and fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and two children. She earns a living by running a retail store where she sells canned goods, detergents, batteries and other items. She has been in this business for five years and is applying for a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more items to sell to her customers. She joined HSPFI earlier this year as a way to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en: Gerlie is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and two children. She earns a living by running a retail shop where she sells items such as canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has been in this business for five years and is applying for a loan for PHP 7,000 to buy more items to sell to her customers. She joined HSPFI earlier this year as a way to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sovera

texts.en:
Sovera is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 4 children. Sovera has a food shop that sells homemade sausage or longganisa. She has had this business for 8 years.  

She requested a loan of PHP 11,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for making homemade longganisa. Sovera has been a member of HSPFI since 2004. In the future, Sovera hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making homemade longganisa

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet wants a loan to buy groundnuts and beans to resell. She lives in Masindi-Uganda, and is a single mother charged with the responsibility of taking care of her two children. She started four years back with capital of 200,000 but now her working capital is 6,000,000 shillings. She desires to educate her children and to be a big produce dealer having mills of her own.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts and beans for reselling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is 60 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 5 children.  Lolita has a food shop that sells viands, like chicken & pork adobo, pancit bihon & afritada . She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy raw ingredients for making viands.  Lolita has been a member of HSPFI since 2007. In the future, Lolita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making viands

loans.name: Rebie

texts.en:
Rebie is married and lives in Pan-taon Ozamiz City. She has a two children who are in school. Her husband is a farmer. 

She is engaged in planting and harvesting vegetables to earn a living. She sells vegetables like root crops, "gabi"behind her, string beans, okra and others.  Rebie delivers her harvested vegetables to her contract buyer in the market. She has been in this business for 5 years and earns about 7,000 Philippine Pesos. 

She joined GDMPC in the year 2009. She is applying a loan of Php 5000 to purchase fertilizers for her vegetable garden for increased growth of the plants

In the future, she plans to own a house and lot. Rebie is renting a house for the family.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert, 27, lives in his own house in Masindi, Uganda. This married father of two children has been a taxi driver for five years, having earned his initial investment capital from the motorcycle business. Robert is now requesting a loan to service his car, and his goals are to buy a min bus and educate his children.

loans.use: to service his car.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 24 years old and single.  He runs a retail shop selling electrical goods.  He has been operating this business for four years.  He employs two people to assist him in the business.  

Michael is requesting a loan for  60,000 Kenya shillings, which he will use to renovate his business premise and add stock of sockets, switches, and electric cables.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business and has become more financially stable. His desire is to open other outlets of his business in five years.

loans.use: to renovate his business premises and add stock of sockets, switches, and electric cables.

loans.name: Aden

texts.en:
Aden is 35 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in the Philippines. Aden has a retail shop that sells fish such as sardines and mackerel. She has had this business for five years. 

Aden is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fish to sell. Aden is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Aden hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Tafuta Upate Group

texts.en: Anathaus, who is in her early 30s, is married with two children who go to school. She has been a tailor since 2004. She works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. This will be her third motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania given in the middle of the main loan that motivates borrowers with good credit ratings who pay back their loans smoothly to receive half the amount of the existing loan before their original loan term has ended. She used the previous loans to buy materials and managed to make a lot of bedsheets and tablecloths, and has paid back her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy more stock of materials, kanga and vitenge (different types of traditional African cloth). Her dream is to one day be able to own a grocery. She will share this loan with her loan group "Tafuta Upate," which has a total of seven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more stock of materials, kanga and vitenge (different types of traditional African cloth).

loans.name: Benard

texts.en: Benard used his previous loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a room to rent out.  Now, he gets extra income from the rental room.  Benard also runs a retail shop. He has requested another loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of sugar, cooking fat, soda, soap and rice.

loans.use: To add stock of sugar, cooking fat, soda, soap and rice

loans.name: Heart

texts.en:
Heart is 21 years old and single. She lives in the Philippines. Heart has a retail shop that sells clothes such as shirts, underwear, and pants. She has had this business for two years. 

Heart is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy clothes to sell. Heart is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Heart hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Hann

texts.en:
Hann is 17 years old and married. She is from Ornlong Veng district, Siem Reap province. She runs a small retail business, selling mixed products like groceries, snacks, sweets, packaged biscuits, drinks, and other similar products to the people in her community. She earns approximately $2.00 per day. Her husband is also in retail, selling fast food and drinks from his three-wheel cycle. 

Hann is requesting a loan from HKL, which she will use to buy a motorcycle to support her husband's business. In the future, Hann wants to own a grocery store in a local market.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle to support her husband's business.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is 56 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is separated and has 3 children. Merlyn has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. 

She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.  Merlyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Merlyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Saom

texts.en:
Mrs. Saom, a 59 year-old married mother of two children, is a very hardworking farmer who grows rice crops in the rainy season of the year. She also takes some time besides farming to buy and resell her bamboo baskets in various places together with her husband. Through those businesses, she can generate a profit of $2.5 per day. 

Saom is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a few plots of farmland.  She will be able to grow more rice crops and make more profit for her family. 
In the future, she will greatly expand her basket-selling business if she has a good market place.

loans.use: to purchase a few plots of farmland.

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed and has 4 children. Tita has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years.

She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages. Tita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Tita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 37 years old and married with four children. To earn a living, he sells fish and runs a grocery. He has been in the business for five years. Previously, he used to sell clothes. 

Boniface has been able to improve his business since he joined Faulu Kenya because of his previous loan. He hopes to fully establish his business in five years. He has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to expand his business premises.

loans.use: to expand the business premises.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is single. She is 48 years of age. She is from the village of Kapalaran, Tambulig Zamboanga del Sur.

Anecita is engaged in planting and harvesting rice to sell to earn a living. She has been in this business for five years and she has a return per cropping of PHP 15,000. She is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for the next cropping. Her rice field is ready for planting. 

She became a member of GDMPC this year only to gain financial access for her rice production. Anecita plans to expand her rice field to save money for her old age. She doesn't have family. Her earnings are for her food and other basic needs. She helps her neighborhood. She compensates those people who helped her during harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for the next cropping

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen is 46 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with eight children. 

Carmen has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Carmen is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Carmen hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children.
 
Myrna has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Myrna is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Myrna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is 30 years old and married. He sells clothes to earn a living. He runs his business in a competitive environment, but he is able to retain his customers because of his good reputation. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become more focused on his business. Charles hopes to open more business outlets in the future. He needs a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy trousers.

loans.use: to buy trousers

loans.name: Livilita

texts.en:
Livilita is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is separated with four children. 

Livilita has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for 4,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

Livilita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Livilita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Sron

texts.en:
Mrs. Sron, a 47-year-old married mother of a single child, is in the business of doing laundry, earning around $2.00 per day. Her house, which she in in the process of rebuilding, is located in Ornlong Veng District of Siem Reap Province.

Having used all of her saved money to purchase the needed materials for her home, Sron is now requesting a loan from Kiva of $800 to hire people to perform the actual construction. She hopes that this will result in a comfortable house in which to live.

loans.use: to hire people to construct her house.

loans.name: Balimi S.h.g Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Balimi S.H Group in Western Kenya! Joseph is the facilitator of Balimi S.H. group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.  As with the majority of the population in this part of Kenya, the members of Balimi S.H Group rely on maize farming for food security and income. 

Joseph takes care of six children at home with he wife.  He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Joseph had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Joseph was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Joseph and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Joseph will educate his children, feed his family throughout the year, and invest in livestock. 

In 2012, the members of Balimi S.H group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is 54 years old, married, and has six children.  She lives in the Philippines. Carmelita has a retail shop selling canned goods, snacks, and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. 

Carmelita is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages. Carmelita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Carmelita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Zusima

texts.en:
Zusima is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Zusima has a shop that sells spices & food seasonings like red bell pepper & rock salt. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy spices & food seasonings for sell
.
Zusima has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Zusima hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy spices & food seasonings to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 37 years old and married and with two children in school.  He sells eggs, paraffin and charcoal to earn a living.  He has been in the business for six years and has employed one person. Previously, he worked as a mechanic. Most of his customers are low-income earners because his business is located in the slum area. 
 
George hopes to expand his business and buy a kerosene pump to sell kerosene.  He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy paraffin and charcoal.

loans.use: To buy paraffin and charcoal

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is 29 years old, single, and has one child.  She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Five years ago Sarah began buying and selling new clothes. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy clothes to sell.  She hopes to educate her child and expand her business so as to realize maximum profits.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 62 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed with seven children. Teresita has a retail shop that sells bananas and vegetables like spring onions and string beans. She has had this business for 25 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos to buy vegetables and bananas to sell.

Teresita is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Teresita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and bananas to sell

loans.name: Cerila

texts.en:
Cerila is 51 years old, married, and has two children.  She lives in the Philippines. Cerila has a food shop selling snacks such as piniato, peanut roll, and yema or milk candy. She has had this business for 10 years. 

Cerila is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy raw ingredients for these snacks.  Cerila is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Cerila hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for snacks.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence is a 57-year-old married man with six children living in a semi permanent house in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He has been farming cocoa and also trading in it for the last 20 years. He intends to use this money to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 23 years old and single.  He raises pigs to earn a living, which he has been doing for two years. He has retained his business because of his hard work and determination.

Stephen is requesting a loan for 30,000 Kenya shillings, which he will use to buy pigs. He dreams of practicing large-scale farming in the future.

loans.use: to purchase pigs.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is 29 years old, married, and has six children. She lives in the Philippines. Aida has a retail shop selling canned goods, snacks, and  beverages. She has had this business for five years. 

Aida is requesting a loan for 4,000 PHP, which she will use to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages. Aida is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Aida hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, snacks, and beverages.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Teresita has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Teresita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Teresita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine is 46 years old and she lives in Vanadzor city. Narine is married and has a son and a daughter. Narine graduated from a teachers’ training institute but she has never worked as a teacher. 

For more than 10 years, Narine has been engaged in a clothing and shoes trading business that she organized. She rents a place in Vanadzor's central trade market. Narine’s husband helps her to distribute clothes from Yerevan to Vanadzor. They buy the clothes in wholesale markets. 

Thanks to profit from her clothing and shoes trading business, Narine and her husband provide for their family’s needs and help their pensioner parents. 

Narine is seeking a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian drams to buy winter clothes and shoes for reselling.

loans.use: To buy winter clothes and shoes for reselling

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with six children. 

Amelita has a retail shop where she sells clothing like T-shirts, blouses & underwear. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy stocks of clothing to sell.

Amelita is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Amelita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy stocks of clothing to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Jocelyn has a retail shop where she sells snacks & fruit like bananas. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy snacks & fruit to sell.

Jocelyn is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Jocelyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks & fruit to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes and grocery items for his tuck shop

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is 50 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. 

Lorna has a shop where she sells coconuts & vegetables like spring onions  & string beans.  She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy coconuts & vegetables to sell.

Lorna has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Lorna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy coconuts & vegetables to sell.

loans.name: C6318 Abunzubumwe Group

texts.en:
Theoneste is 44 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of three and seven years old. He is the leader of this group which is called "Abunzubumwe" in the local language. Theoneste has four years of experience selling various foods like beans, cassava, and sweet potatoes. In the photo, he is the man in the middle wearing a red shirt.

Theoneste has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by buying more foods like beans, cassava, and sweet potatoes to sell. With profits from this loan, Theoneste would like to satisfy his family's basic needs and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to purchase more foods like bananas and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Hamamaoko Group

texts.en:
Chengetai is 47 years old. She is married and has two children aged 11 and 7 years old and they both go to school. 

She operates a flea market stand and has been in the business for five years. Her flea market stand is located at a Market in town. She has one employee. She travels to South Africa to purchase her goods. 

With the loan she would like to buy clothes, shoes, and towels to restock her market. She faces a challenge of fluctuation in the exchange rates when converting from US$ to Rands. In the next five years, she would like to own her own shop to sell  her goods from. She will also be able to provide for her children's needs and wants to give them a better education with the profits from the business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes, shoes and towels.

loans.name: Sango S. H. G. B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sango SHG B Group in Western Kenya! This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Nevin is the facilitator of the Sango SHG B group. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Nevin had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Nevin was only able to harvest 9 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Nevin will invest in livestock rearing, build a house and start a business.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Nevin and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Nevin will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Sango SHG B group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

He is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Leofel

texts.en:
Leofel is 33 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Leofel has a food shop that sells chicken and pork barbecue. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy raw ingredients for making barbecue.

Leofel has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Leofel hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making barbecue.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 47 years old, married, and has five children.  To earn a living, he practices farming.  He also does a motorbike transport business to earn a living.  He has employed one person in the business.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access business loans.  This has helped him to boost his business.

Jonathan hopes to grow his business in the future.  He has requested 70,000 Kenya shillings to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.name: Salina Chepkemboi

texts.en:
Salina is 43 years old, married to Paul, and they are blessed with six children. Salina does poultry keeping and she has been in business for 10 years. Right now her monthly income from the business is KES.17,800. She is borrowing a loan of KES 42,000 which she plans to use to purchase poultry feed and more poultry--about 250 in number.

She plans to use the anticipated profit from the business to repay the loan and to expand her business.This is her fifth loan and she successfully repaid her previous loans. Her hope and dream is to educate her children and to build rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed and more poultry.

loans.name: Ezra

texts.en: Ezra is a 35-year-old man married with three children living in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to educate his children and have a sound business. He has been a coffee dealer for the last 12 years and has progressed despite the challenge of coffee price fluctuations. Ezra needs the loan to buy coffee to sell.

loans.use: to buy coffee to sell.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. 

Lorna has a retail shop that sells clothing & beauty products from NATASHA & AVON. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy products from NATASHA & AVON.

Lorna is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Lorna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy products from NATASHA & AVON.

loans.name: Nyamdavaa

texts.en:
Nyamdavaa is a 36-year-old married woman who lives with her daughter in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband works in Korea. Her daughter attends a local high school. Nyamdavaa supports her family by operating a retail clothing stall in the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. When she first began her business in 2002, she had 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) in working capital. Today it’s increased and become 3,100,000 MNT in working capital. 

This is the second time that Nyamdavaa has requested funding from Kiva and she is really thankful to all Kiva lenders for giving her an opportunity to increase her working capital. With this loan of 1,500,000 MNT, Nyamdavaa will purchase more products for the upcoming season.

loans.use: to purchase more products for the upcoming season.

loans.name: Jaribu A Group

texts.en:
Nashon is the facilitator of the Jaribu A group. Nashon and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Nashon and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Nashon joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Nashon had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Nashon was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Nashon will invest in a cow and then build a house.

In 2012, the members of Jaribu A group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 32-year-old married man with four children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to educate his children to higher levels of education. He has been in the motorcycle transport business for ten years and faces a challenge of impassable roads during the rainy season. He started with farming and managed to raise money to buy his own motorcycle.

 Joseph needs the loan to buy another motorcycle for transportation.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle for transportation.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 59 years old, married, and has five children in school.  To earn a living, he does poultry farming.  He has been in the business for three years.  He also practices crop farming for extra income.

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been trained in financial management.  This has helped him to invest his money into his business. He hopes to become the major supplier of eggs in his region in five years.  He has requested 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy chickens (layers).

loans.use: To buy chickens (layers).

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo is a 54-year-old married woman who has been residing in Ornlong Veng district, Siem Reap province. She has owned a general store selling mixed products like sweets, groceries, drinks, packaged foods, and other household products since 2009. She typically makes a profit of $6.00 per day through this business. Presently Keo has run out of products from her stock. Therefore, she is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,000 from Kvia’s funders to purchase additional merchandise to sell. With the increase in income, she will save to improve her business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy timber  for  carpentry work.

loans.name: Wekhakila Group

texts.en:
Geoffrey takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund because of One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Geoffrey had an excellent maize yield harvesting 8 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Geoffrey was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½ acre of land. With income from maize sales, Geoffrey will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

Geoffrey is the facilitator of the Wekhakila group. Geoffrey and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Wekhakila SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Geoffrey and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 39-year-old married man with two children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dreams are educating his children and buying a car. He has been in the motor vehicle spare parts business for the last 10 years and has been challenged by customers not paying on time plus price flactuation and inflation. His goal is to expand his business into a new market. John needs the loan to buy spare parts for sale.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for sale

loans.name: Mulembe Group

texts.en:
Margret takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Margret had an excellent maize yield harvesting 17 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Margret was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize on 1 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Margret will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

Margret is the facilitator of the Mulembe group. She and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Mulembe group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Margret and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Grace Group

texts.en: Eurita is a 50 year-old widow from Harare.   She has four children, all attending school.  Eurita runs a peanut butter manufacturing business. The business has been in operation for 6 years. She says the main challenges faced are shortage of groundnuts, as production is seasonal. She has requested a loan of $400 to buy groundnuts. Eurita says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the family's welfare. In the future, she plans to buy machinery to reduce manual work.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts

loans.name: Umoja Group

texts.en:
Receive greetings from Umoja Group in Western Kenya! With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Fred and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Fred is the facilitator of the Umoja group. He is in the photograph with his group members.This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Umoja group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Fred is the father of two children. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Fred had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Fred was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land. With income from maize sales, Fred will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Amberki

texts.en:
Amberki is from the village Vazisubani, Kakheti Region, East Georgia. He is 24 years old and lives with his parents and 21 year-old brother. Amberki and his parents are involved in family farming activities and his brother works in local car washing service company as car-washer. 

Amberki’s family has 2 calves. Also they have 290 peach trees. The family owns 0.7 hectare of agricultural land, where tomatoes and cucumbers are grown. Amberki sells harvested peaches and vegetables locally to the retailers. Total average monthly income of the family is 800 Laris.  Amberki requested credit for purchasing fuel for tilling the land, in order to get a good harvest of vegetables next season. Also, part of the loan will be used for purchasing a calf. Amberki will sell all three calves in spring for a higher price and get a profit. He plans to use the received profit for improving family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for a tractor for tilling the land, and to buy a calf

loans.name: Otaba Oburi A Group

texts.en:
Josephat is the facilitator of Otaba Oburi A group. Josephat and his group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Josephat and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Josephat takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund's low prices, to ensure food security for his family, and, later, to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Josephat had a good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Josephat was only able to harvest seven bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With income from maize sales, Josephat will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Otaba Oburi group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence is 36 years old and is married with two children. Laurence owns a business selling local drinks and soft drinks. She has one year in this business, and the hours of her work are from 7.30 am until 8.30 pm every day. She currently employs two people to help her.

Laurence has requested a Kiva loan, via Vision Finance Company, in order to purchase more local drinks and soft drinks to sell. With any profits, she will be able to save for her future and she will reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more local drinks and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sofronio

texts.en:
Sofronio is 33 years old and is married to a teacher. He lives in Happy Village, Tambulig Zamboanga del Sur. 

He owns and operates a small grocery store. His business has grown fast because of his hard work.  He has a net income in the amount of 9000 Php a month. He has been operating this business for about 2 years, since he got married. 

In 2011, Sofronio joined GDMPC to have financial access from the cooperative for the expansion of his current business. He is requesting a loan in the amount of Php 10,000 from GDMPC  He has taken a loan previously in the cooperative and he was able to pay on time. The money he borrows is of great help to his business. This is his second cycle of loans taken from GDMPC.  In the future, he plans to have his own house. He hopes that the revenue generated from his business will help him build a house.

loans.use: Purchase additional grocery products to sell

location.town: Happy Village, Tambulig Zambo. del Sur

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo, a 45-year-old single woman who has been living in Reussey Keo commune, works as a civil servant in her commune and gets her salary monthly. Presently, she lives with her niece, 31years old, who is a dressmaker. Besides working, Keo wants to use her time to operate a used clothes business for more profit, yet she has inadequate capital to start it. So she decided to ask for some funds from HKL, a longstanding partner of Kiva, to purchase a stock of used clothing for selling. This loan will improve Keo’s standard of living. With the income she’ll earn, she will use some of it to fix her house.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of used clothing for selling.

loans.name: Ageuni Group

texts.en:
Christine is the facilitator of Ageuni group. Christine and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Christine and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Christine takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to have access to its low prices, to ensure food security for her family, and, later, to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Christine had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Christine was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With income from maize sales, Christine will educate her children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Ageuni group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land. 

In the picture the person standing on the far right is the field officer.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Amon

texts.en:
Amon is 51 years old and is married, with eight children.  He owns a shop selling various goods, such as juice, soap, biscuits, cakes, etc.  Amon has five years' experience, and the hours of his business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day except on Sunday. He currently employs one person to help him.

Amon has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase various goods, such as lotions, soap, biscuits, etc., to sell.  With any profits from the loan, Amon would like to satisfy his family' basic needs and start saving for his future.  He will be able to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase various goods, such as: juice, soap, biscuits, cakes, etc.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 40 years old and married to Veronicah.  They are blessed with six children. He runs a retail shop and he has been in business for two years. Right now his monthly income from the business is KES.3,000.  He is requesting a loan of KES.20,000 in order to add more stock to the business. 

He plans to expand his business and to educate his children with the anticipated profit from the business. This is his third loan, and his hopes and dreams are to open a big shop in future.

loans.use: To add stock, like sugar, bathing soap, tea leaves.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 43 years old and widowed, with four children.  She owns rental houses, which earn her a living.  She has employed one person in her business.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to educate her children.  This is because she has improved her business. 
Mary hopes to build other outlets of her business in the future.  She has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenya shillings to install separate power meters for the rental rooms.

loans.use: To install separate power meters for the rental rooms

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine used the previous loan to buy clothes and shoes to sell in her shop.  Now she sells first-class clothes and her business is progressing, despite the hardships of a constant increase in prices of goods.  She needs the loan to buy new clothes to sell in her shop as she targets the Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her shop

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en: Beatha is 38 years old and is married with two children aged 7 and 12 years old. Beatha owns a business selling timber. This is her third successful year in this business. She works from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. every day except Sunday. Beatha has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her timber sales business by buying more timber for resale. With any profits, she will be able to save in her future, reinvest in her business, and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more timber for sale.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en: Constance is 30 years old. She owns a business selling adult and children's clothes. She has one year's experience in this business and the hours of her work are from 7 am until 7 pm every day except on Sunday. She currently employs one person to help her. Constance has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase clothes to sell. With any profits, she will reinvest in her business and be able to pay for her master's education and save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase adult and children's clothes to sell

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is 30 years old, married and with two children. She sells clothes to earn a living. She has been in the business for ten years and has employed two people. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to improve her business with a previous loan. Caroline hopes to open a boutique in the future. She has requested for a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kamo

texts.en: Kamo is 51 years old. He lives with his wife, two sons, a daughter-in-law and mother in Vanadzor city. He has collage education. Kamo has been engaged in the animal-breeding business for several years. He organized his farm in Shahumyan village which is near Vanadzor city. Kamo’s family helps him in the farm. The meat produced in Kamo’s farm is delivered by his son to Vanadzor’s markets and meat shops. Kamo is also working part time in Vanadzor’s water supply center as an operator but the main income comes from animal breeding. The profit helps Kamo to take care of his family's needs. Kamo asks from a Kiva 900.000 Armenian drams loan to buy fodder for his farm animals.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his farm animals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy 10 crates of soda to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to service his car he uses in transporting milk.

loans.name: Sirare Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sirare Group in Western Kenya! Dorcas is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 
 
Dorcas is a mother to three children. She joined One Acre Fund due to the affordable rates of loan repayment offered by the firm and in order to grow enough to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Dorcas had a good maize yield harvesting six bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Dorcas was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Dorcas and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Dorcas will invest in livestock rearing and repay her loan. 

In 2012, the members of Sirare group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured in the photograph with her group members and their Field Officer to the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Patricie

texts.en:
Patricie is 24 years old, married, and has four children. She owns a business selling various goods such as: soap, fruits, lotions, etc. She has had this business for two years and works from 7:30 a.m. until 8:30 p.m. every day. She currently employs two people to help her. 

Patricie has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase various goods such as: soap, fruits, lotions, etc. to sell. With any profits she makes, she will save for her future, reinvest in her business, and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase various goods such as: soap, fruits, lotions, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Hope C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Hope C Group in Western Kenya! Rosemary is the facilitator of the Hope C group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Rosemary takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rosemary had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rosemary was only able to harvest 1.5 bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rosemary and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, she will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Hope C group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

In the picture the field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Nyota A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Nyota A Group in Western Kenya! Gladys is the facilitator of the Nyota A SHG group. Gladys takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access the most competitive prices for fertilizer and quality seed. In the recent 2011 season, Gladys had an excellent maize yield harvesting 30 bags on 1.5 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Gladys was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1.5 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Gladys will pay for school fees and other major annual expenses for the family. 

This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of Nyota A SHG group will each plant between 1 and 2 acres of maize. With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Gladys and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February, 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Ndungu

texts.en:
Ndungu is a 32-year-old married man with four children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been a taxi driver for ten years. He was formerly an employee and now has his own car. His vision is to buy another car and to educate his children.

Ndungu needs the loan to buy tires.

loans.use: to buy tires.

loans.name: St. Anthony Bidii Group

texts.en:
Jane takes care of 10 children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, she had an excellent maize yield harvesting 6 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jane was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on ½ acre of land. With income from maize sales, Jane will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

Jane is the facilitator of the St. Anthony Bidii group. She is in the photograph with her group members and the Field Officer is standing to the left. Jane and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. In 2012, the members of St. Anthony Bidii group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jane and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 29 years old, married, and has two children. To earn a living, she sells potatoes. She also does tailoring to earn extra income. Through Faulu Kenya, she has been able to improve her business because she has been trained on business management skills. Diana hopes to open other outlets of her business in the future. She has requested a loan of 35,000 KES to purchase more potatoes.

loans.use: To purchase potatoes

loans.name: Kezeroni

texts.en: Kezeroni needs another loan to buy sugar and soap for resale. He is a hardworking man whose dream is to become a wholesaler. He has challenges of limited finances to meet the increasing demand of his customers. He used the previous loan to purchase soap and sugar. With the profits he was able to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to buy sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Saverino

texts.en: Saverino is a 45-year-old married man with six children. He has been operating a retail shop for one year. He acquired the initial capital to establish his business by selling his bull. His hardships are price fluctuations, inflation, and inadequate capital. His personal goals are educating his children, buying a car, and building a permanent house. His business goals are moving his business to a more permanent location and expanding it to new markets. Saverino intends to use the loan to buy sodas and salt for resale.

loans.use: to buy sodas and salt

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en: Batbayar is 43 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic dwelling) in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business, his elder son is a college student, and his younger one is a school student. He started his meat retailing business in 2002 by renting a counter in a market. He has many regular customers who only buy his products. Now that winter is approaching, he needs to save some stock before prices get high. He is a sharp and hardworking person who said, "I need to do everything I can to pay my kid's college fee." He is requesting 550,000 MNT to buy livestock.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a widow with seven children, one of whom attends school. The others have already graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of inadequate food supply for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' demand.

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sacks of beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, and sacks of beans.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a 29-year-old married man with three children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the coffee trade for one year. Previously he was in a retail shop business. His hardship is insufficient capital. His vision is to be prosperous and to build a residential house. Robert needs this loan to buy coffee.

loans.use: to buy coffee to sell.

loans.name: Muungano Group

texts.en:
Yohana is the facilitator of the Muungano group. Yohana and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Yohana is a father of four children. He joined One Acre Fund in order to to access fertilizer and hybrid seed and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, He had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Yohana was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Yohana and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Yohana will build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Muungano group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Yohana is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Phebis

texts.en: Phebis needs another loan to buy clothes to sell. With the previous loan, she was able to purchase clothes and used the profits to restock her business. Her capital has increased to five million shillings.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a thirty-six-year-old married woman with six children and she owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been operating a retail shop for one year after switching from selling fish. Her hardship is inflation and her vision is to expand her business. Grace needs the loan to buy sugar to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar to sell.

loans.name: Jambaldorj

texts.en: Jambaldorj is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. His wife works in a petrol station and the two kids are school students. He started his transportation business in 1994 with his own truck. Now, he has renewed his old truck and bought a sedan with the business profits. Now that winter is approaching, he needs to maintain his truck by buying four tires and fixing the engine. He is a sharp and diligent man who says, "I have a vision to buy an even bigger truck and a house of my own." He is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to buy four tires and to maintain the truck for the harsh winter.

loans.use: To buy four tires and maintain his truck for the harsh winter

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a coconut selling business, selling from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business. 

With the Kshs 10,000, she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale.

loans.name: Salveri

texts.en: Salveri needs another loan to buy cosmetics to sell.  He operates a retail shop and was able to purchase a motorcycle with his previous loan.  He believes in multiple businesses and now wants to venture into cosmetics sales.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 33 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has 3 children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past five years, Charles has been working hard to manage his retail shop which stocks spare motor parts and motor oil. 

To help expand his business, Charles has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy spare parts for resale, and will help Charles to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Charles hopes that in the future he will be able to own a bigger shop for spare parts. 

Charles is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Charles who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for resale.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 40 years old, married, and has five children.  To earn a living, he sells dried fish.  He has been in this business for almost two years.  He employs one person in the business.  

He has managed to boost his business with his previous loan from Faulu Kenya. George hopes to expand his business in the future. 

He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy dried fish.

loans.use: to buy dried fish.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is 38 years old and lives in the town of Mubende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is widowed and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past two years, Teopista has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells drinks like beer. 

To help expand her business, Teopista has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beer and soda for resale, and will help Teopista to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Teopista hopes that in the future she will be able to start another business. 

Teopista is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Teopista who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more beer and soda for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a single woman who lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past seven years she has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier of charcoal in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a divorced woman with five children, two boys and three girls, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a coconut selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation and seasonality in her business. Her product is found in the rural areas with poor road networks, hence making her business difficult to operate. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers’ needs in the future. 

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts as a supply during festive season. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts as a supply during festive season.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is requesting another Kiva loan of 40,000 KES to boost her charcoal selling business.  With the loan she wants to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for resale. 

Asha dreams of expanding her business to become a wholesale supplier in the future. Thanks to Yehu and Kiva lenders for providing her loan so she can improve her business and her standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
Firuza is 32 years old and has worked as a cattle breeder for the last 5 years.  She is married and has three children.   Her husband works as driver but his salary is not permanent and very low.  

Cattle breeding is the main source of income for Firuza's family.  Her monthly income from selling cattle is 80 AZN.  

She would like to expand her business and purchase two additional cattle and fodder.  She requests a 1000 AZN loan. 

This will be her third loan and she has a good credit history.

loans.use: to expand her business and purchase two additional cattle and fodder.

loans.name: Bintiali

texts.en:
Bintiali is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated real estate houses to earn a living.  Bintiali's potential customers are tenants from the neighboring community.  She dreams of establishing more real estate houses in the future.

With a Kshs 20,000 loan, Bintiali wants to renovate her real estate houses and purchase paintings.  

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to renovate her real estate houses and purchase paintings.

loans.name: Sarvan

texts.en:
Sarvan is a 32 years old man who breeds and sells sheep. He has four years of experience in this field. 

He is married and has four children.  He usually buys lambs, raise and fatten them and sells them in the livestock bazaar to people who want meat and fur. 

Sarvan`s income is 150 AZN per month.  His father actively helps Sarvan run the business.  Now he has applied for 1200 AZN loan to purchase 15 lambs and fodder.

loans.use: to purchase 15 lambs and fodder.

loans.name: Latafat

texts.en:
Latafat is a 36 years old woman who has bred sheep for the last 5 years.  She is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) who lives in Bilasuvar, a IDP settlement with her husband and three children. 

Her monthly income from selling sheep is about 150 AZN.  It is their family's primarily source of income.  Her husband actively helps Latafat look after the sheep. 

Now she would like to expand her activities and purchase one milk cow.  She applied for 700 AZN loan to do that.  

Latafat has already demonstrated herself to be a good client with a positive credit history.

loans.use: to expand her activity and purchase one milk cow.

loans.name: Murad

texts.en: Murad is 40 and married with two children. Murad has been engaged in sheep and cattle breeding for the last eight years. Murad usually sells sheep for wool and meat and keeps cows for milk production. Milk, meat and wool sales are his main financial income source, and they make about 300 AZN per month. Now Murad has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase one more cow and sheep.  Murad has already demonstrated himself to be a good client with a positive credit history.

loans.use: to purchase one cow producing more milk and six sheep

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is a married woman with two children, all of whom have graduated from school.  She owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a cosmetic and clothes selling business.  Zainabu sells door to door to her neighbors and to passersby.  She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation.  Her dream is to become a retail supplier of beauty products and clothes in the future.

With a Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase beauty products like facial creams, body lotions and bundles of clothes to sell during festive seasons. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products like facial creams, body lotions and bundles of clothes to sell during festive seasons.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more sheep and a milk cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase two milkier cows.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 28 years old farmer who raises and sells seasonal fruits and vegetables.  He is IDP (Internally Displaced Person).  He has four years of experience in farming. 

Ali also works in construction as a laborer during the winter season.   He is married and has three children.  Ali's monthly income from farming is about 250 AZN. 

Ali's wife helps him run the business.  Being their main source of income, Ali is seeking financial support.  For this purpose, he applied for a 1000 AZN loan.  This will be his second loan and he has a positive credit history.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and organic fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase one milk cow and two cattle.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty  lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children, two of whom go to school. She takes care of two additional family members, a brother and sister.  She is a retail mushroom farmer.  Betty works seven days a week. She has been in this business for the last 3 years. She has requested a loan of 900000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more millet and mother spawn. Betty generates additional income by selling charcoal stoves and renting rooms. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to build more rental houses and to become a big mushroom farmer. She lives in her own house and her family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy millet and mushroom spawn.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food, school fees and rent bills.

With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting, she wants to start a food vending business and purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, potatoes and cooking fat and oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, potatoes and cooking fat and oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two dairy cows and one beef cow.

loans.name: Samangul

texts.en: Samangul is a 34-year-old poultry breeder. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) and lives with her husband and four children in Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. She has 5 years of experience in poultry breeding. She breeds goose, chicken and turkey, depending on the season. In winter, goose is the most popular poultry; in spring and autumn turkey is the most popular, and chicken is popular throughout the year. Her business generates a stable income of 140 AZN per month, but this is too low for her big family. She applied for a 1200 AZN loan to purchase more poultry in order to meet market demand and improve life conditions for her family. This will be her second loan from AqroInvest and she has a good client history.

loans.use: to purchase more poultry to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children, one boy and two girls. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a juice selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also sells charcoal which contributes to her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season, the demand for juice is lower. Fatuma dreams of establishing a juice parlor in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase a juice blender for making fruit juices for sale and also to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a juice blender for making fruit juices for sale and also to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with 5 children all of who go to school. She takes care of two additional family members (old parents: mother and father). She has a retail shop. She operates a retail business. Mariam works six days a week. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She has requested a loan of 2,000,000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, rice, flour, and cooking oil. Mariam generates additional income through poultry farming. Her major business challenges are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to own a wholesale shop and also to educate her children to university level. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and food.
